When is the last date I can confirm my intent to enroll in my graduate program?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The last date to confirm your intent to enroll is approximately two weeks before classes begin to ensure we can process your enrollment and get you all set for the first day of classes. However, it does take time to process your Intent to Enroll confirmation, as well as register, so we encourage all admitted students to confirm their intent to enroll as soon as possible. You can find instructions on how to submit your intent to enroll on the Office of Admissions Next Steps for Admitted Students page: https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/next-steps-for-admitted-students/graduate-student. 

Please keep in mind that certain programs may have specific times by which you should submit your intent to enroll. If your program has a specific deadline in which you must respond to your admission, you will be notified by the program directly.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Why was I admitted into a Master's program when I applied for a PhD?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
In some cases, the department to which you applied may make the decision to admit you into the master’s program because the faculty has determined that at present, your credentials are best suited for master’s level work. If you would like to be re-considered for the PhD program, you will need to contact the department to which you have been admitted for assistance. Please keep in mind that you may be required to resubmit an application and fee if you wish to be re-considered for the PhD program.

You can find contact information for Mason graduate programs here: https://www2.gmu.edu/academics/graduate-programs.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Are there specific course requirements for undergraduate admissions?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
We do not have specific course requirements in regards to a student's admission. When reviewing applications, the Office of Admissions will look to see if students are challenging themselves and that students meet the requirements to graduate. If the student is taking a course that is affecting their GPA, we will leave it to the student's discretion on whether to drop the course.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I review my recommendations from my graduate admissions application?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
If you have chosen to retain your right to review your recommendations and have been admitted and enrolled at Mason, please send a written request to masongrad@gmu.edu. 

If you have chosen to waive your right to review your recommendations, we cannot share those documents with you.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I reopen my graduate admissions application to a future semester?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Fortunately, all applicants can request a reopen of their incomplete application one time free of charge within one year of the original application term. Please notify the Office of Graduate Admissions of your desire to reopen your application by email to masongrad@gmu.edu, including your G#, full name, program, original semester, and the new semester to which you would like to reopen. Your request must be received within the deadline for the semester you wish to re-open. Once we receive this information, we will notify the application specialist of your desire to reopen your application and the specialist will determine if you are able to reopen your application and notify you of any next steps. You may also be eligible to reopen your application if your application was completed but your program was full so your application could not be reviewed by faculty. Unfortunately, your application cannot be reopened if you failed to pay your application fee, or if you have reopened this application in the past.

If it is after the original application’s deadline and your application remains incomplete, or if your program is full, you will be able to request to reopen your application once your application has been cancelled by the University. If your application is cancelled, you will receive a “Cancellation Notice” in your Self Service Center and can “Respond” to this notice to request a reopen. If eligible, you will receive an email from the Graduate Admissions Office with next steps on how to submit your supplemental reopen application free of charge. Unfortunately, your application cannot be reopened if you failed to pay your application fee, or if you have reopened this application in the past.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What are the allowable special grades for my course?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
SA (stopped attending) and NA (never attended) are transformed to grades of F on a transcript. HC (honor charge) is transformed to a grade of NR (not reported). IP (In Progress) is appropriate for courses in which the student is expected to continue to develop their research, writing or project until a future semester, such as for a thesis or dissertation, a practicum or internship. A grade of IN (incomplete) is usually the appropriate grade for missing work and calculates as an F while on the student’s record. IN and IP should not be assigned as midterm grades. 

Please refer to the Registrar's website for details regarding special grades.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How can I transfer credits into my new degree program?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
If you would like to have credits transferred into a graduate program, you must contact your department after acceptance to fill out a credit transfer request: http://registrar.gmu.edu/wp-content/uploads/GTC.pdf.

Once approved by the department, the request must be turned into George Mason’s Office of the Registrar.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Which special grade should be notated for a student?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
AB (Absent from the Final Exam) A temporary grade of AB may be given to students with prior approval of their dean/director to be absent from the final examination.

AU (Audit) In order to receive a grade of AU, students (unless they are a part of the Senior Citizen Waiver Program) are required to submit a Course Audit form.

HC (Honor Code) Use this grade if an honor code violation is suspected and will be filed with the Dean of Students (Office of University Life). A special code NR (Not Reported) will appear on the student’s record.

IN (Incomplete) You may assign a grade of incomplete only if the student meets the catalog requirements for this grade. The University Catalog states: “The grade of IN may be given to a student who is passing a course but who may be unable to complete scheduled course work for a cause beyond reasonable control.” An incomplete is a contract between the instructor and the student and should not be given unless pre-arranged. Work must be completed at the latest by the end of the ninth week of the next semester and grades submitted by the tenth week (not including Summer Term). Instructors may require a shorter deadline. In this instance, an Incomplete Grade Contract must be submitted.

NA (Never Attended) Use if the student never attended the course. NA is an internal notation. The grade of F will appear on the student’s transcript.

SA (Stopped Attending) Use if the student stopped attending the course. You must give the last date of attendance in the ‘Last Attend Date’ field. SA is an internal notation. The grade of F will appear on the student’s transcript.

W (Withdrawal) If a student has been granted permission to withdraw and the withdrawal has been processed, you will see the grade of W recorded for the student on your roster. Withdrawals are given administratively and are not always granted.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What is the difference between an IP and an IN grade?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
An IN (Incomplete) has the same value as an F. It restricts the amount of time a student has to complete the course work and will automatically change to a grade of F if a grade change is not submitted by the deadline date. A grade of IN should be given only in situations where the student, for reasons beyond their control, is not able to complete the coursework within the normal time span of the course.

An IP (In Progress) is appropriate for courses in which the student is expected to continue to develop their research, writing or project until a future semester, such as for a thesis or dissertation, a practicum or internship. The IP grade is available only for limited, pre-approved courses, most at the graduate level. Students in courses that require continuous registration must be continuously graded as IP at the end of each term of enrollment except the last, when a final grade must be submitted.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I selectively withdraw from a course as a graduate student?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
No, selective withdrawals apply to undergraduate students only. If extenuating circumstances have led to your need to withdraw from a course, please contact your academic department.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How can I obtain a second graduate degree or certificate?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
In some cases, a department may work with an admitted graduate student to add a graduate certificate to their degree program. This process must be done by the student and the department after the admissions process is completed.

If you are interested in a dual degree program, you can determine whether George Mason University offers the two degrees you as a dual degree on the online catalog. If they are offered as a dual degree, you must submit a separate application for each program, with a separate fee for each application. George Mason students also have the option to pursue two individualized master's degrees simultaneously. Please visit the online catalog for more information.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How long do I have to complete my degree? Can I take classes as a full time or part time student?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The length of each program depends on the following: the number of hours needed to complete the degree, the status of the student as full-time or part-time, and the availability of required courses that may not be available during every term.

Many programs will allow you to enroll as a part-time or full-time student, but please note that there are strict time limits for earning a degree based on the level of study.

For more valuable resources, we recommend taking a look at the university catalog for more specific information regarding full-time status, part-time status, time to complete degrees and credits required to earn the degree: http://catalog.gmu.edu/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How can I take non-degree undergraduate level courses when I am a non-degree graduate level student?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Once you have received your admissions decision and have confirmed your intent to enroll as a non-degree graduate student, you may submit a request to take undergraduate courses through the university registrar. Please visit http://registrar.gmu.edu/forms/ to find the "Graduate Student Request for Undergraduate Course Registration." This request must be submitted before the last day to add courses for the term. Please refer to the registration calendar for specific deadlines.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
When is the first day of classes?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
You can find our university calendar, which includes the first day of course for the term, here: http://registrar.gmu.edu/calendars/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
As a graduate student, how do I change my program to a lesser degree?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Graduate students can change to a lesser degree (PhD to MS/MA, MA/MS to CERG) by completing the Graduate Program Resignation and Transfer form with all proper signatures.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Do I have to apply and be admitted if I just want to take one graduate course?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Yes, in order to take any graduate course at George Mason you must first apply and then be admitted. If you are not interested in earning a degree or graduate certificate, you may apply to our university as a Graduate Non-Degree Student: For information on the process to apply as a Graduate Non-Degree Student, please refer to our website at https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/how-apply/non-degree.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How many letters of recommendation are required?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
While many applications require three letters of recommendation, it varies by program. Please visit our Application Deadlines and Requirements section to review the required number for the specific program you are interested in: https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/how-apply/graduate/application-deadlines-and-requirements. If your program requires less than 3 recommendations, we encourage you to only submit the exact number of recommendations required as this is what the faculty of your program has deemed as necessary to consider your application appropriately. However, all applicants to degree seeking programs may submit up to 3 recommendations. Recommendations must be sent electronically via your online application. .

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
My name appears differently on my test than my application name. Will this cause issues?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
If your name appears differently in any way on your test than your online application, this often can cause delays and failure in scores being matched to your application. If this is the case, please email masongrad@gmu.edu with the information about the name you used to submit your application and the name used on your test. If possible, please submit the order confirmation or a copy of the test report along with your email to further assist in locating your scores. You should also include any information about other documents or test scores that may show a different name than the one you applied under, like your transcripts, as this will be important to know.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What transcripts or diplomas do I need to submit?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Applicants considered a domestic applicant will need to submit unofficial copies of all prior transcripts from institutions where degrees were earned. It is recommended to submit transcripts from institutions where 12 or more credits were earned as well. Please note that the Graduate Admissions Office reserves the right to request transcripts that feature less than 12 credits attained where an applicant has attended. If an applicant has an instance where brief academic history is featured on another institution's transcript, like taking a study abroad or summer course, if the credit appears on the degree-seeking institution transcript, but not the grade, we will request the applicant to upload the unofficial transcript from the non-degree seeking institution as well. If the grade appears, but not the credit, then no transcript from the non-degree seeking institution will be required to upload into the application. Transcripts may be uploaded directly in the application by the applicant. Unofficial copies of transcripts are acceptable for application review. If transcripts are international, they may be uploaded into the application as well as unofficial attested copies. If admitted, we would request a set of official transcripts to complete the student's enrollment requirements.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Why is there a fee for application?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The application fee goes towards paying the administrative costs of the application becoming generated to appear in our system. If an applicant believes to qualify for a fee waiver at the undergraduate level, they may check our eligibility criteria on our website. If an applicants believes to qualify for a fee waiver at the graduate level, they may inquire with their desired graduate program to which they are applying for their unique fee waiver eligibility criteria.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
I am a US-educated applicant. Do I have to submit official transcripts and diplomas/degree certificates for my application to be reviewed for admission?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
No. To complete the application, applicants may upload scanned copies of their official attested transcripts for application review. Please make sure the documents are legible. They should include the applicant's full name, show the designated school name, and have the degree conferral date, if already earned. Please keep in mind, if admitted, all applicants are required to submit official, final transcripts prior to the last day to add/drop courses in their first semester or they will be withdrawn by the university..

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do my recommenders get notified to submit a letter of recommendation?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
On the last step of the online application, applicants may input recommender’s email and contact information. As soon as the applicant clicks “send invitation”, the notice will go out to the recommender's email that was requested. Recommendation letters may be put in spam and junk folders, applicants should notify recommenders separately of when recommendation link from the application has been sent. Upon submission of the online recommendation, it will automatically be linked to the application. Applicants may resend the recommendation link by clicking on “send reminder” under the recommender’s name in the Online Portal checklist. In addition applicants may also change recommenders by clicking on “change recommender” in the same section of the Online Portal.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Will I have to reapply later if I want to be admitted to a degree-seeking program?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Yes, applicants must apply to the program of their choice, submit the necessary supplementary materials and receive admission in order to enroll in a degree-seeking program. Please note, acceptance as a non-degree student does not guarantee admission into a degree-seeking program. However, if seeking to maintain Non-Degree graduate level status, as long as a graduate non-degree student takes at least one course a semester, the student will retain graduate non-degree status and will not have to reapply as a non-degree student

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can you tell me if I've been admitted or not?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Once a decision has been made on your application, we will notify you by email that your application portal has been updated with an enrollment decision. The faculty reviewers for each program ultimately make the enrollment decision, and it will be provided on your application portal as soon as it becomes available. Official decision letters are only disclosed via the application portal and are not physically mailed nor detailed within received emails of there being a decision ready to view in your application portal.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
I'm a Graduate student, I know a decision has been made, but I haven't received my decision email. Where is it?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
You may log into your application portal to ensure that a decision has been made. Please keep in mind the official decision letter is the one posted on the application portal, we do not email or mail official decision letters. If you have checked your spam or junk folders and have not received emails from Graduate Admissions, please email masongrad@gmu.edu with an alternate email address for your application so we can ensure you will receive any further correspondences from our office.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
I'm a Graduate applicant, can Mason evaluate my transcript?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
GMU provides transcript evaluation services to applicants free of charge. However, once your transcript items are received, it can take 4-6 weeks for them to be evaluated and returned to the Graduate Admissions Office. Due to this additional timeline, we suggest that you apply at least 60 days in advance of published deadlines if you want to take advantage of this service.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do freshman applicants using the Common Application set up their required Mason Admissions Portal?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Freshman applying via the Common Application will receive an email from Mason Admissions approximately 2-3 business days after submitting the Common Application. This email contains instructions about how to set up their Mason Admissions Portal, which is required to review their admission decision. The Mason Admissions Portal is where applicants check the status of their application, review missing documents, and view their admission decision when it is available.

General instructions for setting up the Mason Admissions Portal:

Visit the Mason Portal

Sign up using the email address used to create your Common Application

Application updates will be available on this site within 24 hours.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I apply as a freshman without test scores?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Freshman applicants have the option to apply to Mason without an SAT or ACT through our Score Optional program. Score Optional review provides an opportunity for students to be considered for admission without submitting standardized test scores whether by choice or by necessity. If you are applying score optional, it is recommended that you maintain a competitive, cumulative high school grade point average for Score Optional consideration. If you have already taken an SAT or ACT and are unsure if you should include them with your application, you may send your test scores in. If the admissions committee determines your application is more competitive without your test scores, your application will be switched to Score Optional. Applying without test scores will not be detrimental to your application, and Score Optional students are reviewed for admission, merit scholarships, and the Honors College in an equal manner with those students who do submit test scores.

Due to SAT and ACT test date cancellations, freshmen applicants to the Volgenau School of Engineering for the Spring 2021 and Fall 2021 terms are exempt from the 550 SAT MATH /24 ACT MATH requirement if they have taken or are currently enrolled in four years of high school mathematics classes, including a course beyond Algebra II by their senior year, and have achieved grades of B or better in each of those courses.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I apply as a transfer student? (Non-GAA)
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

As a transfer student, your application will need to include a completed online application, the application fee, and official copies of transcripts from all of your previously attended colleges or universities.  The application is available online at https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/apply-now  along with additional admission information.
 

The Admissions Committee considers each transfer application individually, reviewing all grades received in courses attempted as well as the rigor of the applicant’s academic program. Competitive applicants present:

24 or more transferable semester hours from regionally accredited U.S. colleges/universities or international universities recognized by their Ministry of Education.
Transferable English Composition and Mathematics course.
Transfer applicants generally present a competitive cumulative GPA of 2.75 or higher (GAA Applicants require a cumulative GPA of 2.85 or higher)
Essay (Optional) 
Resume (Optional)
All applicants to George Mason University are reviewed for English Language Proficiency. If English is not your native language, please review requirements to meet Mason’s English Language Proficiency Requirements: https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/how-apply/international/english-proficiency-requirements
High School transcript and standardized test scores (if you have fewer than 24 college credits complete at time of application)
Additional information on these requirements can be found here: https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/how-apply/transfer. International transfer students can also find more information, including additional document requirements, here: https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/how-apply/international

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What is the transfer application deadline?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The transfer priority deadline for the fall semester is March 1st. The deadline for the spring semester is October 1st.  Students who apply after these deadline are reviewed on a space available basis only. As a result, we cannot guarantee that students who apply after this deadline will be given a decision. To be considered for admission under the Guaranteed Admissions Agreement (GAA), you are required to submit your application by the priority deadlines and must have all required documents submitted no later than 10 days after the deadline.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I defer my transfer application?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

We permit transfer students to request to defer their admission to Mason for a semester. To be able to defer, you have to accept your spot in our class. To do this, you will first need to pay your enrollment deposit: https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/next-steps-for-admitted-students/transfer
 

After you have paid your enrollment deposit; you can formally submit a deferral request at the link below. Please highlight your circumstances and reason for deferring in the deferral request. https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/deferral.
 

Please note that deferrals are contingent upon your application remaining exactly the same during the deferral period. As such, you would not be permitted to enroll in college coursework elsewhere during the deferral period. If you do so, you would then need to reapply.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What is the deadline to apply for Financial Aid?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Financial aid application (FAFSA and VASA) availability and priority submission deadlines can be found at https://www.gmu.edu/financial-aid/how-apply-financial-aid.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
When are freshman applicants notified of their admission decision?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Early Action applicants: Those who applied by the Early Action deadline with Completed application statuses should receive a decision as early as mid-December. 

Regular Decision applicants: The Office of Admissions begins notifying Regular Decision applicants of their admission decision in late March. Not all applicants are notified of their decision in late March; instead, decisions will be released on a rolling basis based upon when an application was submitted and all required documents received.
 

Decisions will continue to be released as space remains in the freshman class. All admission decisions are communicated via the Mason Admissions Portal. Please check your student status page at https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/how-apply/application-status to ensure that there are no pending items that you still need to submit to complete your application.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What are the deadlines for paying for tuition?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Please visit https://studentaccounts.gmu.edu/calendars/ for the most up to date calendar.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I drop my course after the deadline?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Students cannot drop any courses after the drop deadline. If a student would like to withdraw from a course, they can do so via PatriotWeb during the Unrestricted Withdrawal Period. After the Unrestricted Withdrawal Period has passed, students will need to request a Selective Withdrawal. A grade of ‘W’ will be assigned to those courses, and students will be financially liable for tuition. Please refer to the Registrar's Academic Calendar for dates and deadlines for the Unrestricted and Selective Withdrawal periods.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Where can I find the Registrar calendar?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Please visit https://registrar.gmu.edu/calendars/ for the most up to date calendars.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How can I switch sections after the add/drop deadline?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
When switching sections, you are still adding and dropping a class and will need to follow the process for obtaining a Late Schedule Adjustment by contacting the Department offering the course. The Late Schedule Adjustment Form, if approved by the Department Chair, should be submitted to the Office of the University Registrar for processing.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What is the deadline to drop a course and will I receive a tuition refund?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
For information regarding add/drop deadlines and tuition liability, please refer to the Student Accounts Office payment information calendar https://studentaccounts.gmu.edu/calendars/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I still register for a course after the last day to add a course?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
After the last day to add a course, registration via Patriot Web is prohibited. If circumstances warrant an exception to policy, only the Chair of the Department offering the course may grant permission to register for a course after the deadline. The Late Schedule Adjustment Form, if approved by the Department Chair, should be submitted to the Office of the University Registrar for processing.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
When will the graduation application close?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Students can find the graduation application deadline for their graduation term and other relevant deadlines at  https://registrar.gmu.edu/students/graduation/timelines/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
It is after the last day to drop but I still need to drop a class. How can I do so at this time?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
If the selective withdrawal period has ended and you would still like to withdraw from a class, you will need to contact the academic department to inquire about a Retroactive Enrollment Adjustment. These requests are approved at the discretion of the department and you may need to provide documentation of extenuating circumstances that led to your need to withdraw from the course.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
When are transfer applicants notified of their admission decision?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Fall applicants: The Office of Admissions begins notifying transfer applicants of their admission decision on April 1. Not all applicants are notified of their decision on April 1; instead, this is the time frame when we start releasing decision notifications to applicants who submitted all their documents by the priority application deadline, and whose applications have been reviewed by the Admissions Committee.

Spring applicants: The Office of Admissions begins notifying transfer applicants of their admission decision on November 1. Not all applicants are notified of their decision on November 1; instead, this is the time frame when we start releasing decision notifications to applicants who submitted all their documents by the priority application deadline, and whose applications have been reviewed by the Admissions Committee.


Decisions will continue to be released as space remains in the transfer class. All admission decisions are communicated via the Mason Admissions Portal. Please check your student status page at https://www2.gmu.edu/admissions-aid/how-apply/application-status to ensure that there are no pending items that you still need to submit to complete your application.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I add or correct a SSN/TIN on the 1098-T form?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Corrections to a SSN/TIN requires downloading and complete the IRS Form W-9S: https://studentaccounts.gmu.edu/wp-content/uploads/W-9S.pdf

 

Be sure to write your current Mason G number at the top of the form.

 

Do not email the form. 

 

You may send the form via fax: (703) 993-2490 or Mail to:

George Mason University
MSN 2E2, Student Accounts Office
4400 University Drive
Fairfax, VA 22030

 

You may also submit the form in-person or online at the Mason Student Services Center . 

Visit https://studentaccounts.gmu.edu/frequently-asked-questions/ for additional 1098-T FAQs.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I update my address on the 1098-T form?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Address changes can be made at the Patriot Web.  Please ensure that your address is updated using a preferred address by December 31st of the current tax (calendar) year.

 

Additional 1098-T information can be found at https://studentaccounts.gmu.edu/frequently-asked-questions/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION

What are qualified and non-qualified expenses reported on the 1098T?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

As determined by the federal government, qualified expenses are defined as expenses required by and paid to the institution for enrollment purposes. They include fees for tuition, facilities, technology, mandatory fees, and a portion of the course and services fees.

Nonqualified expenses are defined as room and board, student activities, parking, athletics, insurance, equipment, or other similar personal living expenses.

As a result, the amount of qualified expenses will likely be less than the total amount of money paid.

Please visit https://studentaccounts.gmu.edu/frequently-asked-questions/ for additional 1098T FAQs.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
I have a question about my 1098-T form.
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

An extensive list of 1098-T Frequently Asked Questions can be found at https://studentaccounts.gmu.edu/frequently-asked-questions/.

Please note that Mason is not allowed to provide students with tax advice. Visit the IRS website, contact the IRS, or contact a tax advisor for questions on what you may be eligible to claim.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION

Can I request my preferred name on my diploma?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

When a student completes the Graduation Application, they will have the opportunity to choose how they want their name to appear on their diploma. If a student wants to change their diploma name after submitting their Graduation Application they would need to submit the “Diploma Name and Accent Mark Request- online form” found here: https://registrar.gmu.edu/forms/.  

 

The addition of a diploma name is only for inclusion on the diploma and does not modify any name in the system of record.  
If an update to the legal name recorded in the system of record is required, a Change of Personal Information request must be submitted. 
Graduates have until their degree conferral date to update their diploma name which is posted under the Graduation Timelines.  
Updates made after conferral require you to order a replacement diploma.  Standard fees will apply.  

International Students and Graduates Planning to Live or Work Abroad: 

Some countries require that the diploma and official transcripts match for various legal, immigration, and employment purposes. 
Choosing to print a name other than your legal name on your diploma may result in unforeseen complications. 
It is recommended that any student who plans to live, study, or work outside of the United States choose their legal name to be printed on their diploma. 
Additional changes will require you to order a replacement diploma. Standard fees will apply.  

Degree Verifications:   

The University is required to report students’ legal name to the National Student Clearinghouse, which is the entity that provides degree verifications on behalf of George Mason. If you opt to have your chosen name printed on your diploma, be aware that degree verifications will still require the use of your legal name.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Will I be notified that I am graduating with honors?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Undergraduate students who qualify will be sent an e-mail from the Office of the University Registrar informing them of their eligibility to purchase honor cords. Email notification is sent approximately ten days prior to the event. An email is sent to students whose GPA, at the time that the report is run (ten days prior to the event), would qualify them for honors. If a student qualifies based on grades posted after the report is run, Registrar’s Office staff will verify eligibility and notify the Bookstore.

Purchasing Honor Cords
Honor cords will be available for purchase in-person at the University Bookstore at an approximate cost of $20.00. All honors students will wear the same cord regardless of their honors level. 

Honors cords are not available to purchase online and the bookstore cannot take credit card information over the phone. You must have a photo ID to purchase your honor cords.

Eligibility for University Honors and Honor Cords can be found here.

Please contact the Office of the University Registrar at 703-993-2000 or email degree@gmu.edu with any questions regarding eligibility to wear honor cords.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I order an official transcript?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Students who are currently enrolled at Mason can order an official transcript through Patriot Web. After logging in, select ‘Student Services’ then ‘Student Records’. An option to ‘Order Official Transcript’ will be displayed.

If you are an alumni or former Mason student, you can place transcript orders directly through https://registrar.gmu.edu/students/transcripts-parchment/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can my authorized user see my 1098-T?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
By default, they cannot however, you may authorize permission in the Bill + Payment System. Instructions for authorizing a user can be found in the Bill + Payment Guide.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I obtain my official non-credit student record?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

George Mason University maintains a permanent record of your successful completion of Mason-sponsored, non-credit learning activities. These activities include workshops, seminars, and certificate programs that you have successfully completed. George Mason University programs that have been approved by George Mason University Continuing and Professional Education to award Continuing Education Units (CEUs) or Continuing Professional Education credits (CPEs) will be included in your student record. Your records will include the name and date of the event, as well as the number of CEUs awarded. 
 

To request an official non-credit student record, please complete the online 'Non-Credit Record Request' form located at https://registrar.gmu.edu/forms/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
My diploma arrived damaged. How can I order a replacement?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

If damage occurred in transit, our vendor will send a replacement. Just snap a picture of the damaged item and email it to diplomaprints@parchment.com. Please include the DID#. If you are unable to locate your DID# (Document ID), please include your first name, last name and institution name to aid in record location.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION

I submitted a name change request to the Registrar's Office (Change of Personal Information form). When can I order an official transcript through Parchment reflecting my name change?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Once the name change is processed your unofficial transcript will reflect that change. As soon as your unofficial transcript reflects the name change, you may order the official transcript.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I appeal my final grade?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Grade appeal information can be found online in the university catalog at:  https://catalog.gmu.edu/policies/academic/grading/#ap-3-9

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What do I need to do if my final grade is incorrect in PatriotWeb?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
If you believe that your final grade for a course was entered incorrectly, please contact the course instructor for assistance.

Information about Grade Appeals can be found in the university catalog at: https://catalog.gmu.edu/policies/academic/grading/#ap-3-9

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Where can I locate my final grades?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
To view your final grades, you will need to log into PatriotWeb. Once logged in, select the ‘Student Services’ tab, then ‘Student Records’, then ‘Final Grades’. You will then see an option to view your final grades for any term you were enrolled.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
I graduated a long time ago and would like to re-order my diploma. How can I do so?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The university offers alumni the opportunity to order a *replacement copy of their original George Mason diploma. The basic fee for an order mailed to an address in the U.S. is $127.50 per diploma. The cost for international destinations is $197.50. Diplomas will take 1-2 weeks to print after which they are mailed through FedEx Overnight Domestic or FedEx International Priority.

All replacement orders must be made through Patriot Web or through Parchment. To order through Patriot Web, follow these steps:
Log in to Patriot Web (Please make sure that you allow pop-ups from this site).
Click the ‘Student Services’ tab.
Click ‘Student Records.’
Click ‘Order Replacement Diploma.’

If you do not have access to your Patriot Web account, you can order your replacement diploma through Parchment.

*All replacement diplomas will have the word “Reissued” printed in small type at the bottom.
Replacement diplomas will contain the signatures of the current University President, Rector of the Board of Visitors, University Registrar, and may (depending upon the year of graduation) contain the signature of the University Provost in lieu of the college or school’s Dean.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
When will I receive my diploma?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Diplomas are ordered approximately 6 weeks after your degree conferral date. Once they are ordered, you will receive an email to your Mason email address from our transcript and diploma vendor, Parchment Inc., with a link to access your digital diploma. Diplomas will ship approximately 1-2 weeks after they are ordered and students will receive an additional email once the physical diploma has shipped that contains USPS tracking information.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can my diploma be mailed overseas?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Yes. Diplomas will ship to an international address via standard USPS shipping to the address on file in PatriotWeb.

Instructions to verify and/or update your diploma address on file can be found at https://registrar.gmu.edu/topics/update-my-diploma-mailing-address/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Where do I submit forms for the Student Accounts Office?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

With the exception of Direct Deposit Authorizations and Employee Tuition Exemption forms that must be submitted online, other forms for the Student Accounts Office can be submitted online or in-person.

In-person submission:
Mason Student Services Center, Fairfax Campus, SUB 1, first floor, room 1026. Document drop-off hours are Monday – Friday, 9am to 5pm. Please make any necessary copies of your forms prior to arrival and have ID available. Please ensure that student name, Gnumber and any required signatures are listed on all forms submitted. 


Online submission:

Check-in online at MSSC.

When prompted with “Which area of the university do you need assistance with?” choose “Document Drop Off.”

Upon submission, you will receive an email to the address provided, which contains a secure website link for uploading your documents.

Only PDF, JPEG and Word Documents can be accepted. We cannot accept HEIC files or password protected documents.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I update my personal information?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Students may update their legal name, birthdate, social security number, and legal gender online.  
 

To correct the spelling of your name or date of birth, one of the following official documents must be provided: Driver's license, military ID, passport, or birth certificate.  
To change your legal name, one of of the following official documents must be provided:  Marriage certificate, divorce decree, court order, or birth certificate.  
To change or add your social security number, a social security card must be provided.  
To change your legal gender, one of the following official documents must be provided: Passport, government ID, driver's license, or other governmental document.                        
Students may update their chosen name, pronouns, and/or gender identity in Patriot Web.  

International students on a non-immigrant visa must have their request reviewed by Office of International Programs and Services. Please click here to continue to the proper form.

George Mason University employees must submit name change requests to Human Resources and Payroll.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Do I receive a diploma for minors?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Minors will not appear on your Mason diploma but will appear on your official academic transcript. 

To place an order for an official academic transcript, please refer to the Registrar's Transcripts page.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
I accidentally chose the wrong location on my Physical Location Action Item. How do I correct this? 
​
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
This can be corrected in Patriot Web. Login at https://patriotweb.gmu.edu, click Student Services, Registration, Update Student Physical Location.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Will my third minor appear on my transcript?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
A third minor will only appear on your transcript after your degree is conferred.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What date is on the Diploma?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The date on the diploma is the Degree Conferral date for the graduation term. Please visit the Registrar's Graduation Timeline to review your Degree Conferral date. 

https://registrar.gmu.edu/students/graduation/timelines/

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What's on the diploma?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

For graduates prior to Fall 2020:

For both bachelor’s and master’s programs, the name of your major will appear on your diploma. Academic disciplines for doctoral graduates, however, do not appear on the diploma. Concentrations will be listed on your diploma only if you graduate from one of the following degree programs: Bachelor of Individualized Study, Bachelor of Arts or Science in Integrative Studies, Bachelor of Applied Science, and Master of Arts in Interdisciplinary Studies. Minors are not listed on diplomas.


For graduates beginning in Fall 2020:

For both bachelor’s and master’s programs, the name of your major and concentration will appear on your diploma. Individualized concentrations are printed as “Individualized” except for graduates of Bachelor of Individualized Study, Bachelor of Arts or Science in Integrative Studies, Bachelor of Applied Science, and Master of Arts in Interdisciplinary Studies. Academic disciplines for doctoral graduates do not appear on the diploma. Concentrations are not listed on certificates and minors are not listed on diplomas.
 

George Mason (non-Law) diplomas, both graduate and undergraduate, measure 10 inches by 14 inches in portrait format.  Certificate diplomas are 8.5 inches by 11 inches in landscape format.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Do I need to know my G Number to order an official transcript?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
No. You can use your social security number to order an official transcript and we will match it to your Mason records. For instructions on how to place an order for an official transcript, please refer to the Registrar's Office Transcripts page.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can you send just a portion of the transcript?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
At this time, the university is unable to send partial transcripts. When requesting a transcript, your full academic record at Mason will be sent.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Where will my honor status be notated on my student record?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
If a student graduates with honors, the level (Cum laude, Magna cum laude, Summa cum laude, or with Recognition) will be reflected on the student's diploma and official transcript.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How can I order a transcript if I don't have a g number or social security number?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
To place a transcript order without a g number or social security number, under "Student ID" on the request form, please enter "G00000000" (G followed by 8 0's) and we will manually match your records using your name and date of birth. For more information on how to place a transcript order, please visit: https://registrar.gmu.edu/students/transcripts-parchment/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I place an order for an official transcript over the phone or in person at the office?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
No, all orders must be placed online through the portal for current students or through the Parchment website for former students. For more information about how to place a transcript order, please visit: https://registrar.gmu.edu/students/transcripts-parchment.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I get a copy of my unofficial transcript?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
You cannot order an unofficial transcript, but you can view your unofficial transcript free of charge on your Patriot Web account. To view your unofficial transcript, log in to PatriotWeb and select "Student Services" then "Student Records." You will then see an option to "View your Unofficial Transcript." 

If you do not have access to Patriot Web, please contact IT Services at 703-993-8870 or support@gmu.edu.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can I include other documents with my transcript when it is mailed?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Student are able to send transcripts with an attached document. While placing an order, you will have the opportunity to upload a PDF, word, or image file you wish to be included with your official transcript request. The document will be sent along with the transcript.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How much does an official transcript cost?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Transcripts are $10 per request. Additional charges apply for express delivery.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What impact does a "W" grade have on my record?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
All withdrawals results in a grade of W on the student's transcript for the withdrawn course(s). While a grade of W does not affect the GPA, undergraduate students should note that withdrawn courses are part of "attempted credit hours," which serve as the basis for the student's credit level.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
If I repeat a course, will the previous attempt still show on my transcript?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Yes, all graded course work will show on your official transcript.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can a transcript order be sent by express mail?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Students should contacting Parchment Inc., the third party vendor Mason uses to process transcripts, to inquire about express orders. Please call 833-781-7236 between the hours of 8am – 4pm PST to reach their support team. For instructions on how to place a transcript order through Parchment, Inc., please visit the Registrar's website https://registrar.gmu.edu/students/transcripts-parchment/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How can I enter a final grade when the CRNs are not listed?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
If the course that you are trying to grade does not appear on your list of CRNs, it indicates that you are not listed as the instructor of the course. Please contact your departmental scheduling coordinator for assistance. They will work with the Registrar’s Office to get the instructor of record corrected.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Who can enter the final grade when the instructor cannot enter them due to an emergency?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
If the instructor of record is unable to enter grades because of an emergency or has questions about policy or deadline dates, they should contact the department’s Grading Coordinator. These staff members have been appointed within academic departments, colleges and schools.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How can I confirm that my change of grade has been processed?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Students are able to view final grades and any grade changes the day following submission via Patriot Web. The grade displayed to the student will always be the latest grade submitted.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What is the deadline for an instructor to submit final grades?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
University guidelines recommend that final grades be submitted as soon as possible after administration of the final exam for the course but not later than 24 hours prior to the degree conferral date of the term. The deadline is inclusive of independent study courses with no exam and regularly scheduled semester-long courses.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Does the midterm grade affect my GPA?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Midterm grades do not become part of the student's official record. They are not calculated in any GPA, and they do not appear on any official or unofficial transcript.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Will I receive a midterm grade?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Midterm progress is reported for all full-semester 100- and 200-level classes, and for 300- and 400-level classes at the discretion of the professor. Students should check with their instructors as to when reports will be complete and available for viewing through Patriot Web.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I verify my GPA?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
To verify your GPA you must order an official transcript. For more information about obtaining a transcript, please visit http://registrar.gmu.edu/students/transcripts.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Is the Dean's signature required when updating a temporary grade to a final grade?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Change of Grade forms recording changes from temporary (IN, IP, AB, HC) to final grades only require the instructor’s signature. Final grades may be changed only for recording or calculation error and always require additional approval.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I verify my address?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Mason cannot verify your address, but you may order an official transcript which will include your permanent address on file in PatriotWeb. For more information about how to obtain a transcript, please visit http://registrar.gmu.edu/students/transcripts.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
When will I be able to view my final grades?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
University guidelines recommend that final grades be submitted as soon as possible after administration of the final exam for the course, but not later than 24 hours prior to the degree conferral date of the term. Students are able to view final grades the day following submission via PatriotWeb. The grade displayed to the student will always be the latest grade submitted.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I verify that I am taking classes? What about classes I have taken in previous semesters?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
To verify your current enrollment, you can order Enrollment Verification through PatriotWeb. After you log in, go to the "Student Services" tab then "Student Records." There you will see an option to "Order Enrollment Verification" which will take you to the National Student Clearinghouse website to obtain your enrollment certificate. 

For official verification of courses you have taken in previous semesters, you can order an official transcript. For more information about obtaining a transcript, please visit our website http://registrar.gmu.edu/students/transcripts/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
If I withdraw from a course, will it affect my Dean's list status?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Degree seeking students who take at least six credits in a semester and earn a semester GPA of 3.50 or higher merit placement on the Dean’s List. Courses subsequently repeated and excluded will not retroactively affect Dean's List status. This notation will be placed on the individual's permanent record.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION

I have a loan deferment request form that needs to be signed. Where can I send my form?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Mason has a paperless process for reporting enrollment information for loan deferments. Early each semester, enrollment information is sent electronically to the lending community and the National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS) via the National Student Clearinghouse (NSC). 

 

Because student enrollment information is provided to lenders and loan servicers automatically, students typically do not need to submit deferment forms. 

 

Please refer your lender to service@studentclearinghouse.org should they have any questions.

For additional information, please visit https://registrar.gmu.edu/students/certifications/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION

How should I report information about my noncitizen parents on the 2024–25 FAFSA form?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Here are some tips for students with noncitizen parents:

 

Parents who don’t have a Social Security number (SSN) will be able to create a StudentAid.gov account to access and complete their portion of your 2024–25 FAFSA form. (This applies for 2024–25 and future forms, not for 2023–24.)

 

The SSN will be blank and disabled on the FAFSA form if the parent doesn’t have an SSN. If the parent has an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN), they should add it to the FAFSA form. If they don’t have an ITIN, they should leave that question blank.

 

If your parent doesn't live in the U.S., they can select their country from the “Country” dropdown menu.

 

If your parent lives and files taxes in a foreign country and doesn’t file U.S. taxes, they will still need to provide consent and approval. They will need to convert the amounts on the foreign tax return into U.S. dollars using the published exchange rate and manually enter their financial information from their most recent foreign tax return into the FAFSA form.

 

If your parent lives in and files taxes with a U.S. territory or a Freely Associated State only, your parent should use the information from that tax return to fill out their section of the FAFSA form.

 

If your parent lives in and files taxes with a U.S. territory or a Freely Associated State, and files a U.S. tax return, contact the financial aid office at the college or career/trade school you plan to attend to determine which tax forms and information your parents need to provide to accurately calculate your federal student aid eligibility.

 

If your parent doesn’t file taxes at all, they will be asked for information about how much they earned from work, rather than being asked for information about specific items on the tax form.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION

Is my parent a contributor when I fill out my FAFSA form?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

A graphic containing the same text below can be found HERE.

 

A parent means your legal (biological or adoptive) parent or a person that the state has determined to be your legal parent. A stepparent is considered a parent if they have adopted you. Stepparents who have not adopted you will be identified as a parent spouse.

 

[Question 1] Are your biological or adoptive parents married to each other?

 

[Yes] Your parents’ marital status is married (not separated), and both of your parents’ information must be included on the FAFSA form. If your parents did not file taxes jointly, then both of your parents are contributors. Their individual information, consent and approval, and signatures will be required on the FAFSA form. If your parents filed taxes jointly, only one parent is required as a contributor and will report information for both parents.

 

[No, then answer question 2]

 

[Question 2] Do your biological or adoptive parents live together?

 

[Yes] Your parents’ marital status is unmarried (both legal parents living together), and both of your parents are contributors, even if they were never married, are divorced, or are separated. Their individual information, consent and approval, and signatures will be required on the FAFSA form.

 

[No, then answer question 3]

 

[Question 3] Did one parent provide more financial support than the other over the past 12 months?

 

[Yes] The individual information, consent and approval, and signature of the parent who provided more financial support over the past 12 months will be required on the FAFSA form, and this parent will be identified as a contributor.

 

[No] The individual information, consent and approval, and signature of the parent who has the greater income or assets will be required on the FAFSA form, and this parent will be identified as a contributor.

 

[Question 4] Has this parent married/remarried?

 

[Yes] Your parent’s marital status is married/remarried. Your stepparent will also be identified as a contributor on the FAFSA form if they didn’t file their taxes jointly with your parent.

 

[No] Your parent’s marital status is single (never married), separated, divorced, or widowed. An additional parent will not be identified as a contributor.

 

 

Note: Dependent students are required to report parent information on the FAFSA form, and in most cases, a parent will be identified as a contributor for these students. All contributors are required to provide their information, signature, and consent and approval to have their federal tax information transferred directly from the IRS into the FAFSA form. Being a contributor on the FAFSA form does not mean an obligation to pay for the student’s education.

 

Updated September 2023

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION

What changes were made to the FAFSA?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

The 2024-2025 FAFSA opened on December 31, 2023. This date is different than past years when the FAFSA was available each year on October 1.

 

What is Mason’s 2024-2025 FAFSA priority deadline?

NEW: For priority consideration of limited funding, undergraduate students must submit their 2024-2025 FAFSA by March 1, 2024.

 

When will Mason receive my submitted 2024-2025 FAFSA?

The Financial Aid Office will begin to receive 2024-2025 FAFSAs in early February.

 

Why did the FAFSA availability date change?

On Dec. 27, 2020, Congress passed the Consolidated Appropriations Act which includes the FAFSA Simplification Act—a sweeping redesign of the processes and systems used to award federal student aid. Specifically, the law makes it easier for students and families to complete and submit the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA®) form and expands access to federal student aid. Implementation of these changes to the FAFSA delayed the release of the annual form.

 

While the 2024-2025 FAFSA is available on December 31, 2023, the period following Dec. 31, 2023 is a soft launch. This soft launch period will allow Federal Student Aid (FSA) to monitor and respond in real time to any potential issues impacting the FAFSA applicant experience. During this time applicants may experience a waiting room feature and/or delays which will help control website volumes to ensure optimal performance of the form.

 

 Besides the FAFSA availability date, what else is changing?

 

The term “EFC” (expected family contribution) is changing.

With the 2024-2025 FAFSA, the term Expected Family Contribution (EFC) will be replaced with the Student Aid Index (SAI) – this is a new need analysis formula that we will use when awarding need-based grants and scholarships.

 

No benefit for having siblings in college

The FAFSA previously divided the EFC proportionally based on the number of the household in college. The elimination of this "sibling discount" will be the biggest change in aid eligibility for some students. As such, students with siblings in college may see a change in their aid eligibility, as well as, with the aid received by their sibling(s) at Mason or elsewhere. The determination to no longer consider number in college was made by Congress and can only be changed by Congress.

 

Streamlined application

You’ll notice fewer questions when completing the 2024-2025 FAFSA and an easier way to transfer tax information directly from the IRS.

 

New terminology

You’ll notice a few new terms like contributor (anyone who is asked to provide information on the FAFSA, a parent or student spouse for example) and consent (each contributor will need to consent to their information being included on the FAFSA).

 

Learn more about the 2024-2025 FAFSA changes here.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I submit verification documents requested by the Financial Aid Office?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

With the exception of citizenship documentation and the *Statement of Educational Purpose (SEOP), all verification documents (including tax returns and schedules, V1, V4 and V5 worksheets) must be submitted online in Patriot Forms .

Note that the MSSC cannot accept verification documents in-person or via their online case submission link. 

Please visit Patriot Forms (Verification) for step-by-step Patriot Forms account creation instructions.

 

*Effective 9/27/2023: The Statement of Educational Purpose may only be submitted in-person at the MSSC, or notarized and mailed to the Office of Student Financial Aid. Students will see these two submission options and instructions when they log in to Patriot Forms.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How can I be considered for the VirginiaTwo-Year College Transfer Grant Program (CTG)?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Virginia Two-Year College Transfer Grant Program (CTG)

Under this program, qualifying undergraduate students who complete their Associate’s Degree at a Virginia two-year public college and then transfer to a participating Virginia four-year college or university may be considered for the CTG award.

How Much Can A Student Receive?

This grant is awarded to students enrolled at participating four-year institutions
Maximum annual standard award is $1,000 ($500 per term)
Additional $1,000 ($500 per term) for students enrolled in specific degree programs in: science, teaching, engineering, mathematics, or nursing
Amount may be reduced if the new grant results in an over award
State grant funds may be reduced if you receive a Transfer Grant
Any CTG award may be reduced subject to funding availability and the anticipated number of eligible students
A CTG award might be unavailable if a student’s eligibility is confirmed after funds have been exhausted
Any CTG award may be reduced if there is an over award (total financial assistance cannot be greater than the student’s Cost of Attendance). Note that the CTG awards can affect eligibility for other need-based aid


Eligibility Information for the CTG

A student must:

Be a first-time entering freshman no earlier than fall 2007 (this refers to the first-time student is degree-seeking at any college)
Be an undergraduate in-state student
Meet selective service requirements
Have received an Associate’s degree at a Virginia two-year public institution, and submit a final academic transcript to the Admissions Office as soon as the Associate’s degree is posted
Have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or greater on a scale of 4.0 for the Associate’s degree
Enroll full-time into a Virginia four-year public or Virginia four-year private nonprofit college or university by the fall or spring semester following completion of Associate’s degree
Enroll into a degree program not for religious training or theological education
Have applied for financial aid by completing the FAFSA  by March 1
Have sufficient financial need: defined as a federally calculated Expected Family Contribution (EFC) of 12,000, or less


To be eligible for renewal of the grant for up to three years or 70 credit hours, a student must:
 

Continue to maintain a college GPA of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale
Continue to demonstrate financial need and meet EFC requirements
Continue to maintain satisfactory academic progress
Any break in eligibility after initial award terminates all future eligibility




FAQ’s

Q. When will the CTG be awarded?
A. The Financial Aid Office will verify eligibility as of the Enrollment Freeze Date, which is after the add/drop period.


Q. My bill is due at the beginning of the semester - I need to know if I qualify for CTG before then.
A. CTG funds will not be awarded by the tuition due date each term and students should not expect funds prior to late fees being assessed. In addition to verifying each student’s enrollment after the Enrollment Freeze date, the Financial Aid Office must wait for final funding approval from SCHEV. Once funding has been confirmed the Financial Aid Office must review students for eligibility and submit a roster and invoice to SCHEV for approval. This process often results in funds being awarded as late as October (fall) and March (spring).


Q. Do I need to submit an application for the CTG?
A. While not required, it is strongly recommended that students who wish to be considered for the CTG complete the application for the Virginia Two-Year College Transfer Grant. Submission of the application speeds up the review time for students who wish to be considered for funding. Without an application we cannot guarantee that a student will be reviewed as the application alerts the Financial Aid Office to review your record for missing requirements.

The CTG application can be found at: https://www.schev.edu/financial-aid/financial-aid/federal-state-financial-aid/two-year-college-transfer-grant. The application may be submitted in-person at the Mason Student Services Center or online at mssc.gmu.edu, Virtual Services, Document Drop-Off.


Q. I just submitted my CTG application. Can I get a status update or an idea of whether I might be eligible?
A. No. Students are not reviewed for eligibility until after the Enrollment Freeze date. Please refer to the CTG eligibility criteria listed above. 


Q. I do not have an Associate’s Degree but I was awarded a Certificate from my Community College. Can I be considered for the CTG?
A. No. The CTG requires an earned Associate’s Degree from a VA Two Year College. A Certificate does not fulfill that requirement.


Q. Should I submit my final Community College transcript to the Office of Admissions, Financial Aid or both?
A. Please send your final transcript electronically, to the Office of Admissions. Doing so allows transcript access by both the Office of Admissions and Financial Aid.

Applicants with Northern Virginia Community College transcripts are required to send a Parchment transcript. The Office of Admissions will not accept a paper transcript.

 
Transcripts from other institutions must be transmitted directly from the Registrar at your previous school(s) to the George Mason University Office of Admissions at ugtrans@gmu.edu.


Q. I submitted my final Community College transcript to the Office of Admissions. I am now being told that it is not considered final.
A. Final transcripts must display your graduation date and degree earned or they will not be considered final. Note that an earned Associate’s Degree is required. A Certificate does not meet eligibility requirements.


Q. What happens if I am awarded a CTG but my balance is already paid in full?
A. If the disbursement of a CTG creates a credit on your student account, those funds will be issued to you as a refund. It is strongly recommended that you sign up for direct deposit of refunds at X.


Q. Are CTG funds awarded in the summer?
A. No. CTG funds are only awarded in the fall and spring terms.


Q. I was awarded CTG funds but one of my other grants was reduced. Why?
A. Just like the CTG, the Commonwealth Grant and Virginia Guaranteed Assistance Program (VGAP) are funded by the State of Virginia.  SCHEV limits the total amount of VA grant funding that a student may receive. Based on a grant equity formula supplied by the State of VA, the Financial Aid Office may need to reduce existing State funding to prevent an over award of aid.


Q. I was told I am not eligible for the CTG. Can I appeal that decision?
A. No. As requirements are determined by the State, the Financial Aid Office is not able to make exceptions for funding eligibility requirements. 


Q. Where can I find additional information about the CTG?
A. Additional information can be found at https://www.schev.edu/financial-aid/financial-aid/federal-state-financial-aid/two-year-college-transfer-grant.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION

What is Loan Exit Counseling?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

You must complete loan exit counseling when you leave school or drop below half-time enrollment. The purpose of exit counseling is to ensure you understand your student loan obligations and are prepared for repayment. Exit Counseling can be completed at https://studentaid.gov/exit-counseling/ and should take approximately 30 minutes to complete.

Note: If you leave Mason and plan to enroll in another institution, you are still required to complete exit counseling.

Additional exit counseling information can be found at https://studentaid.gov/exit-counseling/.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Are DACA or undocumented students eligible to complete the Mason scholarship application?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The Mason Scholarship Application includes both merit-based and financial need-based internal scholarships. Consideration for need-based scholarships requires the a FAFSA submitted by February 1 (March 1 for transfer students).

Undocumented and DACA students may file the VASA instead of the FAFSA, and the annual priority deadline is February 1.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
If I graduate early, or do not use all eight semesters of my scholarship can I still receive that money?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER

Students who complete their undergraduate program in fewer than eight semesters forfeit the remainder of their scholarship. Please review Mason’s Merit Scholarship Policy for additional information.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What is the Presidential Scholarship?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The Presidential Scholarship is a program of support for incoming Doctoral students. It is intended to help Mason doctoral programs become more competitive in recruiting students who demonstrate exceptional academic achievement and are committed to excellence in their field of study. This scholarship includes a 12-month Graduate Research Assistantship with a stipend of at least $31,000, 18 tuition credits (9 in the Fall and 9 in the Spring semesters), health insurance subsidy, and is renewable for up to four years.

For additional information, visit Presidential Scholarship.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How does a change in residency affect my scholarship eligibility?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Certain merit scholarships are awarded based on residency status at the time of admission. These merit awards may be reduced or cancelled if a student's residency status changes at any point in their academic career. Review the Mason Merit Scholarship Policy for additional information.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Are international students eligible to complete the Mason Scholarship Application?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
The Mason Scholarship Application is open to all continuing undergraduates, admitted transfers, and graduate students. International students are eligible to apply for Foundation scholarships that do not require U.S. citizenship or financial need. The application process may vary by college or department. Students should contact their respective department for further information about the scholarships offered through their program.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I apply for Mason Foundation Scholarships?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Foundation scholarships are open to all continuing undergraduates, admitted transfers, and graduate students, to review and apply for scholarship opportunities offered through the annual Mason Scholarship Application. The application process may vary by college or department. Students should contact their respective department for further information about the scholarships offered through their program.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
How do I apply for a Grad PLUS loan?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
All Graduate students who are interested in applying for a Grad PLUS Loan must first complete a FAFSA at studentaid.gov. Once the Office of Student Financial Aid electronically receives your FAFSA, you will be notified via email of your initial aid eligibility.

If your estimated cost of attendance has not been met by an unsubsidized loan offer, and if you need additional aid, you may apply for a Grad PLUS Loan. To apply for a Grad PLUS loan, visit studentaid.gov, select the "In School" tab and then select the "Apply for a PLUS loan for Graduate School" link.  To begin the application, you will need to log in with your FSA ID.  

PLUS loan applications for the new/upcoming school year (fall) will be available each year after July 1. 

Visit https://www.gmu.edu/financial-aid/types-aid/loans for additional Grad Plus Loan information.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Where can I find additional scholarship opportunities?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Outside scholarships are offered through private agencies and organizations such as high schools, community organizations, scholarship foundations, employers and government agencies. Criteria for these scholarships generally include academic performance, financial need, underrepresented groups, volunteerism, heritage, community affiliations or other unique factors important to the sponsoring individual or organization. Students are encouraged to apply to as many external scholarships as possible. Please visit the Office of Student Financial Aid's Outside Scholarship List for additional information.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
What are the requirements to continue receiving my merit scholarship?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
To remain eligible for your scholarship, you must meet the terms and condition of Mason's Merit Scholarship Policy.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Am I eligible for Financial Aid?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
Financial Aid eligibility is based on several criteria including but not limited to:
 
Degree Status
Enrollment 
Satisfactory Academic Progress
Citizenship
Financial Aid consideration requires the annual submission of a FAFSA at studentaid.gov. Please visit the Office of Student Financial Aid website for additional eligibility information.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
My parent was approved for a Federal Direct Parent PLUS Loan. How long will it take the Financial Aid Office to certify the loan?
knowledge-base.answer:
ANSWER
PLUS loans are certified once a week. Please allow 7 to 10 days after approval for the loan to be visible in Patriot Web. Note: In order for your Financial Aid Counselor to certify your parent’s PLUS loan, you must have a FAFSA on file, have submitted all requested documents, be meeting Satisfactory Academic Progress (SAP), and be enrolled at least half-time.

knowledge-base.question:
QUESTION
Can incoming freshman apply for Mason Foundation Scholarships?
